citeinfo.title: Soil properties and soil radioisotope activity across Breton Sound basin wetlands (2008-2013)

citeinfo.origin: Smith, J.E., Bentley, S.J., Snedden, G.A., White, C.
citeinfo.title: What Role do Hurricanes Play in Sediment Delivery to Subsiding River Deltas?

descript.abstract: This dataset contains vertical profiles of soil bulk density, percent organic matter, percent total carbon and cesium-137 activity from the surface down to 50-60 cm deep at 25 marsh locations across Breton Sound basin, Louisiana. These data will provide information related to rates of vertical accretion, organic and mineral accumulation and carbon burial in wetland soils across a large portion of the Mississippi River delta plain.
descript.purpose: The sustainability of coastal wetlands largely hinges on their ability to accrue elevation capital at a rate that equals or exceeds relative sea-level rise. A better understanding of these processes is needed to accurately assess the sustainability of these landscapes, and to predict their response to restoration measures such as sediment delivery through river diversions. The data presented here, collected at 25 marsh sites in Breton Sound basin, Louisiana, between 2008 and 2013 with coring tubes 60 cm long and 10 cm in diameter, provide a means to assess whether accrual of elevation capital in this region can keep pace with sea-level rise, and provides insight into the region's sustainability in the coming decades.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

procstep.procdesc: Radioisotope samples were collected with 10cm diameter, 60cm long aluminum coring tubes. Tubes were inserted into the marsh soil, removed, transported back to the laboratory, and frozen at -80 deg C. Once frozen, soil cores were extruded, and sliced into 2-cm depth increments. One quarter of each core slice was used to analyze soil for bulk density, loss on ignition, and total carbon. The remaining 75% of each core section was used for quantification of Cs-137 activity via gamma detection.

enttyp.enttypd: text spreadsheet with soil properties and radioisotope activity

attr.attrdef: core section location along vertical depth profile

rdom.attrunit: 2-centimeter increments starting with 0-2 cm and increasing with depth

attrdomv.udom: grams per cubic centimeter (g cm-3); "." indicates no data

attr.attrdef: proportion of soil sample mass eliminated by combustion at 550 degrees C for 24 hours

attrdomv.udom: grams per gram (g/g); "." indicates no data
disintegrations per minute per gram (dpm/g); "." indicates no data
disintegrations per minute per gram (dpm/g); "." indicates no data

enttyp.enttypd: text spreadsheet with latitude/longitude coordinates for soil cores

overview.eaover: A file entitled "breton_sound_cores_legend.xlsx" is included that serves as a brief data legend. It describes a brief summary of the variables in the datasets, including their attribute names, a brief descriptor of each attribute, the units the attributes are reported in, their range, and some other notes that may be helpful to users of these data.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty
